text:
Marie Curie Avenue (Exterior Street), south from 70th Street, showing excavating work at the right where the New York Hospital and Cornell Medical School is to be built. Farther south, on the south side of 68th Street, a new laboratory building is under construction for the Rockefeller Institute. The name Exterior Street will not be changed to Marie Curie Avenue until 1935.

August 21, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Neg. ** 1271

A general view of midtown Manhattan as photographed northward from the Consolidated Edison Co. Bldg. Running through the left center is Irving Place and Lexington Avenue. To the right is Third Avenue. Washington Irving High School for Girls is in the center foreground. Across the top, from left to right are the outstanding Metropolitan Life, the New York Life, the No. 10 East 40th Street, the Grand Central and Chanin Bldgs. In the upper right corner Tudor City, the East River and the Queensboro Bridge.

March 27, 1929

New York Edison Company
title: General view - Midtown Manhattan from Consolidated Edison building.

Also shown (left to right) is a portion of Queensborough Bridge, yards of the Colonial Sand and Coal Co., and gas tanks and pumping station of the Consolidated Edison Co. In the left background are shown the Hotel Sherry-Netherland and Hotel Pierre. The vantage point is Welfare Island.
May 4, 1933.

text:
(1)
East River, New York's skyline, from East 97th (right) to East 83rd (left) Streets, showing Hell Gate (center and right) and Mill Rock (right). On the left is shown the Astoria, Queens shore abutting into the river, and across it Carl Schurz Park. The rectangular building, on the extreme right, is a storage house of the New York Edison Company, from East 95th to East 96th Streets. Also shown is the excursion boat 'Calvert' approaching the Triborough Bridge, which is the point of vantage.
July 25, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing a more extensive view of the river in a southerly direction, with the Queensborough Bridge in the background.
July 25, 1936.
title: East River - Shore and skyline of Manhattan between East 83rd and 97th Streets - Queensborough Bridge - [New York Edison Company.]

text:
East River, Queens shore, Astoria, showing the neck of land which protrudes into the East River at Hell Gate and forms Pot Cove on the north and (left) Halletts Cove on the south. On the tip, where the river bends, was located old Fort Stevens. Some marble works, the Tisdale lumber and coal yards, an iron foundry, and other manufacturing plants line the shore. Also shown is Manhattan and the Queensboro bridge.

P. L. Sperr

July 25, 1936
Views 1,2,3
title: East River - Queens shore - Astoria - [Tisdale Lumber and Coal Company.]

text:
(1)
East River, shoreline, north from East 50th (left) to East 58th Streets, showing prominently two structures, the 15-story Campanile and the 26-story River House; both at 52nd Street. On the extreme right appears a portion of that exclusive residential area, known as Sutton Place.

P. L. Sperr

(2)
A similar view from East 49th Street dock. Note to the right the thoroughfare Sutton Place, an extension of York Avenue. In the summer of 1939 the foreground area will be filled in to carry the new East River Drive around the rim of Manhattan. It was proposed to carry same under the aforementioned thoroughfare by a tunnel but local objections forced the abandonment of this plan.

P. L. Sperr
title: East River - Shore and skyline of Manhattan between East 50th and 58th Streets - Williamsburg and Queensborough Bridges - [Campanile Apartments ; River House.]

text:
A general view of Midtown Manhattan and the Queensboro Bridge from one of the Grand Central-42nd Street skyscrapers. The Long Island City shoreline of the East River is separated from Manhattan by Welfare (Blackwells) Island.

1938-9

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

text:
East River shore and skyline--Manhattan: A view north from the foot of East 32nd Street, showing the river frontage prior to the constructional fill required for the new East River Drive. At the left is the N. Y. Steam Company. The massed chimneys of the Consolidated Edison Company plant are beyond. In the distance appears the Queensboro Bridge.

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

title: East River - Manhattan shore [from East 55th Street.]

text:
East River, Manhattan, Shore and Skyline, north from E. 58th Street and under the Queensboro Bridge (at 59th Street). Retaining wall at the left supports a small thoroughfare that extends between these two points. This is Riverview Terrace and has houses on its westerly side facing the river. At its northerly extremity is the New York Steam Company plant and which appears at the left margin. Beneath same is its coal receiving platform. Present plans call for the usage of the rocky area in the foreground during construction of the East River Drive. At this date the rock drilling for same is underway at 54th Street and shortly will proceed to this location.

February 9, 1939

P. L. Sperr
title: East River - Shore and skyline of Manhattan from East 58th Street - Williamsburg and Queensborough Bridges - [Riverview Terrace.]

text:
Queensboro Bridge, viewed northeastward from the foot of East 57th Street in Manhattan. In the foreground is the concrete roadway of the new East River Drive. Thru the midground and under the center span is Welfare Island with its new hospital buildings erected by the City with federal aid.

May 12, 1940

Gift of George Jiranek
Photostat Division
New York Public Library
title: Bridges - Queensboro [Queensborough] Bridge - [View of the bridge from East 57th Street in Manhattan.]
